{{Infobox person | name = Chen Tianhua
{{lang|zh-hans|陳天華}} | image = chentianhua.jpg | alt = Chen Tianhua | caption = Chen Tianhua | birth_name = | birth_date = 1875 | birth_place = [[Xinhua]] | death_date = {{Death year and age|1905|1875|12}} | death_place = [[Tokyo]] | nationality = [[Chinese people|Chinese]] | other_names = | occupation = | known_for = }} {{Chinese name|[[Chen (surname)|Chen]]}} {{Chinese text}} '''Chen Tianhua''' ({{zh|t=陳天華|s=陈天华|hp=Chén Tiānhuá}}; 1875 – 1905 December), was a [[Chinese people|Chinese]] revolutionary born in [[Xinhua]], [[Hunan]] province to a poor peasant family during the [[Qing dynasty]]. ==Biography== ===Early life and education=== Chen did not begin his formal education until he was fifteen. He did study [[Chinese classics]] from local teacher. He enrolled into the new-style [[Qiushi Academy]] in his hometown Xinhua in the late 1890s.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EisnZHAMbqkC&pg=PA48 |title=Modern China: An Encyclopedia of History, Culture, and Nationalism|author=Wang Ke-wen|year=1998|publisher=|location=|isbn=0-8153-0720-9|page=48|accessdate=2010-06-28}} ===Political career=== After receiving the shengyuan degree in 1902, Chen was sponsored by the academy to study in Japan 1903 on a government scholarship. He became a radical politician soon after reaching Japan, and wrote two pamphlets which were popular among revolutionaries, ''A Sudden Look Back'' and ''An Alarm to Awaken the Age''.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QiM2pF5PDR8C&pg=PA298 |title=Manchus & Han: Ethnic Relations and Political Power in Late Qing and Early Republican China, 1861-1928|author=Edward J. M. Rhoads|year=2001|publisher=University of Washington Press|location=|isbn=0-295-98040-0|page=13|accessdate=2010-06-28}} He returned to China after seven months and helped found an anti-Qing revolutionary group engaged in insurrection in [[Changsha]], Hunan. He was forced twice to flee to Japan after the closure of his journal Liyu Bao and the failure of a planned insurrection against Qing.[http://www.renditions.org/renditions/authors/chenth.html Chen Tianhua 1875-1905] In response to [[Russian Empire|Russian]] and [[Japan]]ese imperialism in [[Manchuria]], he used his blood to write a few dozen letters that were distributed in schools in China. He was an editor of newspaper ''The People's Daily'', and wrote a novel called ''The Lion's Roar''.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Eazcy0Zrt7QC&pg=PA253 |title=Intellectuals in revolutionary China, 1921-1949: leaders, heroes and sophisticates|author=Hung-yok Ip|year=2005|publisher=Routledge|location=|isbn=0-415-35165-0|page=294|accessdate=2010-06-28}} Chen Tianhua wrote in May 1903, a two part critique published in the Shanghai journal Subao entitled ''On the Corrupt and Rotten Hunan guanbao''. Chen criticized the gazette's contents for being too milited, prodding it to add essays and news and to slip free of the provincial authorities.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OgrM1S1m84cC&pg=PA215 |title=China's local councils in the age of constitutional reform, 1898-1911|author=Roger R. Thompson|year=1995|publisher=Harvard Univ Asia Center|location=|isbn=0-674-11973-8|page=98|accessdate=2010-06-28}} He joined the Anti-Russia Voluntary Patriotic Corps and in 1903 which he reorganized into the Headquarters of National (Guomin Zonghui) along with [[Zou Rong]].The organization quickly evolved into the anti-Manchu Association for the National Military Education (Junguomin Jiaoyuhui). A few months later, Chen returned to China as a representative of the association to promote revolution. In early 1904 Chen, together with his fellow Hunanese Huang Xing and Song Jiaoren, founded the underground revolutionary society China Arise Society (Huaxinghui) in Changsha. He worked with other members of the society to incite armed uprisings among the Qing troops and secret societies.{{cite web|url=http://www.bookrags.com/tandf/chen-tianhua-tf/|title=Modern China: An Encyclopedia of History, Culture, and Nationalism Chen Tianhua (1875–1905)|last=Wang|first=Ke-wen|publisher=|accessdate=2010-06-28}} He integrated traditional values into a pattern of racial unity in his pamphlets, which were read throughout the Yangzi valley. He argued that men are close only to people of their own family, and that when two families fight, one only assists one's own family. He argued that the Han race was one big family, and that the [[Yellow Emperor]] is the great ancestor. All those who were not Han were from exterior families. Kin terms were infused into racial rhetoric that called for emotional expressions. "Racial feeling begins at birth. For the members of one's own race, there is surely mutual intimacy and love: for the members of a foreign race, there is surely mutual savagery".{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uG-rAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA117 |title=The discourse of race in modern China|author=Frank Dikötter|year=1992|publisher=Stanford University Press|location=|isbn=0-8047-1994-2|page=117|accessdate=2010-06-28}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ys5oy66VjisC&pg=PA17 |title=The construction of racial identities in China and Japan: historical and contemporary perspectives|author=Frank Dikötter|year=1997|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|location=|isbn=0-8248-1919-5|page=17|accessdate=2010-06-28}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wkBELsijHmkC&pg=PA26 |title=Images of Westerners in Chinese and Japanese literature, Volume 1997|author1=Theo d'. Haen |author2=Hua Meng |author3=Sukehiro Hirakawa |year=2000|publisher=Rodopi|location=|isbn=90-420-0750-8|page=26|accessdate=2010-06-28}} In 1905 he helped Dr. [[Sun Yat-sen]] found the [[Tongmenghui]]. He committed suicide in [[Tokyo]] bay by drowning to protest against Japanese restrictions imposed on the activities of Chinese students in December 1905. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Warlord era}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chen, Tianhua}} [[Category:1875 births]] [[Category:1905 deaths]] [[Category:People from Loudi]] [[Category:Hunan First Normal University alumni]] [[Category:Chinese revolutionaries]] [[Category:Tongmenghui members]]
